content: How can I generate a funny example for the idiom "Bite off more than one can chew" using Ruby code? Please provide a code snippet as an example.

Certainly! To create a funny example for the idiom "Bite off more than one can chew" using Ruby code, we can simulate a scenario where a character tries to take on too many tasks simultaneously and ends up overwhelmed. Here's a fun little script to illustrate this:

```ruby
class TaskOverload
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
    @tasks = []
  end

  def add_task(task)
    @tasks << task
    puts "#{@name} decides to take on: #{task}."
  end

  def attempt_tasks
    puts "\n#{@name} bravely attempts to tackle all the tasks at once..."
    if @tasks.size > 3
      puts "Oh no! #{@name} has bitten off more than they can chew!"
      puts "#{@name} is now frantically juggling tasks: #{@tasks.join(', ')}."
    else
      puts "#{@name} successfully manages to complete all tasks!"
    end
  end
end

# Example usage
character = TaskOverload.new("Alex")
character.add_task("Learn Ruby")
character.add_task("Cook dinner")
character.add_task("Write a novel")
character.add_task("Run a marathon") # Adding one more task to tip over the limit

character.attempt_tasks
```

In this script, we have a character named Alex who ambitiously tries to take on multiple tasks. When the number of tasks exceeds three, it humorously illustrates the idiom "Bite off more than one can chew" by showing Alex overwhelmed by the tasks. Feel free to adjust the script or add more tasks to see different outcomes!
